caption_text: React qnt asphaltene The present interpretation of asphaltene structure and usage of terms is illustrated schematically in Fig. 1. Asphaltene was regarded as a blend of hydro- carbon particles, defined as covalently bonded olig- omers of unit sheets with a maximum degree of polymerization of 5. The unit sheets comprised be- tween 2 and 30 six-membered rings which could, in turn, be either aromatic or saturated.

caption_text: The predicted molecular weight distributions in Fig. 5 can be indirectly assessed through comparison of the average molecular weights of the sulfur- and vanadium-containing compounds in asphaltene be- fore and after pyrolysis at 400 C for 30 min (Savage et al., 1987). As shown in Fig. 6, pyrolysis shifted the molecular weight distribution to lower values. These results, if generally true for all of the asphaltenic constituents, are in qualitative accord with the model s predictions.

caption_text: The temporal variations of the H/C atomic ratio of the particles and the fraction of carbon atoms in aromatic locations (L) from simulated asphaltene pyrolyses at 42S ~C are portrayed in Fig. 7(a). The H/C atomic ratio decreased from 1.20 initially at 0.85 at 120 min. The value off,, on the other hand, increased from an initial value of 0.42 to 0.61 at 120 min.

caption_text: The predicted variation of the H/C ratio is in good accord with experimental results (Savage et al., 1987) from asphaltene pyrolysis at 400 C shown in Fig. 7(b). The predicted temporal variation of f, in Fig. 7(a) is in qualitative agreement with the results of Al-Samarraie and Steedman (1985) for asphaltene pyrolyses in tetrahin where the value of f, increased steadily from 0.62 for the reactant asphaltene to 0.80 for asphaltenes recovered after pyrolysis at 450 C for 300 min. caption_text: Experimental data (Savage et aL, 1985, 1987) are provided in Fig. 9 for comparison. The simulations at 400 C resemble the experimental results from pyrolysis at 350 C except that the model predicts the formation of low yields of coke. The simulated pyrolysis proceeded at a slow reaction rate and effected an ultimate asphaltene conversion of 27% at 120 min.

caption_text: Representative numerical values used herein are provided in Table 1. Inspection of Table 1 shows, for instance, that 45% of all unit sheets in the model contained nine or fewer aromatic rings, 50% of all particles possessed three or fewer unit sheets, and 66% of all unit sheets with five aromatic rings con- tained two or fewer saturated rings.
raw_window: Representative numerical values used herein are provided in Table 1.

Inspection of Table 1 shows, for instance, that 45% of all unit sheets in the model contained nine or fewer aromatic rings, 50% of all particles possessed three or fewer unit sheets, and 66% of all unit sheets with five aromatic rings con- tained two or fewer saturated rings.

The numerical values in Table 1 were selected from a composite view of asphaltene structure and composition (Speight, 1972, 1980; Speight and Moschopedis, 1981; Yen et al., l984a, b) and were subject to the constraint that the average structural parameters calculated for the reac- tant asphaltene were consistent with literature values.
table_reason: Only S0 and S1 describe the table content directly; S2 provides external context and methodology, not part of the caption.

caption_text: The numerical values in Table 1 were selected from a composite view of asphaltene structure and composition (Speight, 1972, 1980; Speight and Moschopedis, 1981; Yen et al., l984a, b) and were subject to the constraint that the average structural parameters calculated for the reac- tant asphaltene were consistent with literature values. That the distribution of probabilities for aliphatic chains given in Table 1 is reasonable is confirmed by the reported presence of long-chain n-alkanes (up to C36) in asphaltene pyrolysates (Simm and Steedman, 1980; Savage et al., 1985; Ritchie et al., 1979; Rubinstein et al., 1979; Rubinstein and Strausz, 1979), the detection of long (>C6) n-alkyl substituents in asphaltenes by 3C NMR (Takegami et al., 1980), the calculation of average alkyl chain lengths of three to eight carbons (Ah and Al-Channam, 1981; Boduszynski et al., 1977; Koots and Speight, 1975; Speight, 1970, 1971; Yen et al., 1984a, b), and the nearly equal weight yields of long n-alkanes from asphaltene pyrolysis (Savage et aL, 1985).
raw_window: The numerical values in Table 1 were selected from a composite view of asphaltene structure and composition (Speight, 1972, 1980; Speight and Moschopedis, 1981; Yen et al., l984a, b) and were subject to the constraint that the average structural parameters calculated for the reac- tant asphaltene were consistent with literature values.

That the distribution of probabilities for aliphatic chains given in Table 1 is reasonable is confirmed by the reported presence of long-chain n-alkanes (up to C36) in asphaltene pyrolysates (Simm and Steedman, 1980; Savage et al., 1985; Ritchie et al., 1979; Rubinstein et al., 1979; Rubinstein and Strausz, 1979), the detection of long (>C6) n-alkyl substituents in asphaltenes by 3C NMR (Takegami et al., 1980), the calculation of average alkyl chain lengths of three to eight carbons (Ah and Al-Channam, 1981; Boduszynski et al., 1977; Koots and Speight, 1975; Speight, 1970, 1971; Yen et al., 1984a, b), and the nearly equal weight yields of long n-alkanes from asphaltene pyrolysis (Savage et aL, 1985).

caption_text: Having determined the number of ahi- phatic substituents in the unit sheet, the alkyl chain (or linkage) lengths were then determined by comparing random numbers with the cumulative probability distribution for alkyl chains in Table 1.

The foregoing completed the assembly of the first unit sheet, and the steps outlined above were repeated for additional unit sheets until the entire particle had been constructed.
Additional particles were then as- sembled until the model s basis of 10,000 unit sheets had been included.

caption_text: Since each asphaltene particle was assembled inde- pendently and randomly from the data in Table 1, any combination of aromatic rings, saturated rings, and (1) ahkyl substituents with non-zero probabilities could be selected.
raw_window: Since each asphaltene particle was assembled inde- pendently and randomly from the data in Table 1, any combination of aromatic rings, saturated rings, and (1) ahkyl substituents with non-zero probabilities could be selected.
Thus the reactant asphaltene contained a large number of unique unit sheets and particles, each of which underwent reactions during the simulation.
We emphasize that the model is not of a single, average asphaltene molecule.

caption_text: The structural data in the probability dis- tributions, listed in Table t for the reactant asphaltene, were then updated to reflect the effects of pyrolysis, and 10,000 unit sheets were assembled as reaction products.
raw_window: The structural data in the probability dis- tributions, listed in Table t for the reactant asphaltene, were then updated to reflect the effects of pyrolysis, and 10,000 unit sheets were assembled as reaction products.
Reaction products The simulated pyrolyses produced ahiphatics and product particles comprising at least one unit sheet.

The product particles were assembled using the stochastic procedure described previously for the reac- tant asphaltene particles, and they differed from their precursors only in their degree of polymerization and ~in the length of their terminal ahiphatic substituents.
table_reason: The sentences describe experimental results and methods, not a concise description of table content.

caption_text: The product particles were assigned to one of the solubility-based product fractions on the basis of their molecular weight and H/C atomic ratio as illustrated in Table 2. The H/C demarcation between asphaltenes and coke, set at 1.0 for the high-molecu- lar-weight products from the simulation, was con- sistent with pyrolyses of precipitated asphaltenes (Savage et al., 1987) where the H/C ratio for asphaltene always exceeded 1.0 and for coke was always less than 1.0. Note that dctcrmining the solu- bility of numerous compounds in both heptane and toluene and using their molecular weights and H/C ratios to correlate the results could improve the rules of Table 2.
raw_window: The product particles were assigned to one of the solubility-based product fractions on the basis of their molecular weight and H/C atomic ratio as illustrated in Table 2.

Note that dctcrmining the solu- bility of numerous compounds in both heptane and toluene and using their molecular weights and H/C ratios to correlate the results could improve the rules of Table 2.

asphaltene, or coke product fraction on the basis of its molecular weight and H/C ratio.

Calculating the weight of each particle so assigned, summing these for each product fraction, and dividing by the total weight of all par- ticles in the reactant asphaltene enabled prediction of the weight yields of these product fractions from simulated pyrolyses.
